awd_abstract_narration:
Overview:   The wind over the ocean generates oscillations called near-inertial waves (NIW). The subsequent downwards and equator-ward propagation of these NIWs is a main path for mechanical energy from the wind to travel from the surface into the deep ocean. Via wave-wave interactions and scattering, NIWs and internal tides energize the remainder of the internal wave band. Moreover, NIWs control the local stability of the water column that is relevant for breaking and mixing throughout the ocean's depths. A main dynamical reason for the dominance of NIWs which contain about half of the kinetic energy in the ocean is that the inertial frequency is the lowest available to the internal wave band, and the quasi-horizontal oscillatory motion of NIWs offers little impedance to surface wind stress and stratification. Because of their volatile response to atmospheric (wind) forcing, NIWs cannot be described as part of a "universal" wave spectrum of internal gravity waves and different approaches and theories are needed. 

Intellectual merit: A theoretical and computational effort will be directed at three problems related to the generation and propagation of ocean near-inertial waves (NIWs): (a) the interaction of NIWs with geostrophically balanced eddies, particularly the exchange of energy between eddies and NIWs; (b) the windy generation of NIWs, the role of the beta-effect versus eddy vorticity gradients in accelerating vertical radiation, and the reflection of NIWs from seafloor topography with bottom slopes that are comparable to, or larger than, the wave slope; (c) the interaction of surface gravity waves with NIWs and the partitioning of wind stress between the two modes during the generation process. The processes above control the rate at which the wind works on the ocean internal wave field, the damping of mixed-layer near-inertial oscillations and the downward and equatorward radiation of NIWs. These mechanisms act on time scales ranging from a few seconds (gravity wave frequencies) to weeks (surface-intensified geostrophic eddies). Theoretical developments involve multi-scale analysis, stochastic modeling and averaging. Although parameterization is not an immediate goal of this project, the process-oriented work proposed here is essential to the incorporation of internal-wave physics into comprehensive circulation models. 

Broader impacts: Ocean mixing rates cannot be characterized by a single universal diffusivity and thus it is essential to understand how spatial, temporal and environmental factors affect the supply of energy to the near-inertial peak. This peak contains most of the shear variance that determines Richardson numbers relevant for ocean mixing. Thus this problem is central to modeling and diagnosing the ocean's role in climate, the ocean carbon cycle, the nutrient supply to the euphotoic zone and the intentional deep-water disposal of carbon and other industrial waste products. Understanding the role of internal gravity waves in this context is a long-term goal of the proposal. The project involves both theory and numerical modeling on important current problems in physical oceanography suitable for a doctoral thesis for a physical oceanographer or an engineer. The project involves an international collaboration and will contribute to an effort to attach a phase-averaged NIW model to the Regional Ocean Model System. The project will improve the Wikipedia article "Stokes drift" and expand the stub "Coriolis-Stokes force" into a full entry.

por.por_cntn:
The motion  of air and water in the atmosphere and ocean is a fundamental problem  of fluid mechanics with important applications such as weather prediction, marine commerce, Earth's climate and naval operations. Outstanding scientific issues addressed in this grant revolve around the interaction of different varieties of ocean waves. The most familiar example of an ocean wave  is a "surface gravity wave". These are the easily visible waves that break on beaches and produce sea sickness.  Surface gravity waves  travel across the sea surface with speeds of order meters per second. There are other less familiar examples of ocean waves - particularly "internal waves" which are undular disturbances supported by the density stratification of the ocean. Internal waves can travel vertically  throughout the depth of the ocean, from top to bottom, a distance typically of four or five kilometers. Internal wave speeds are centimeters per second i.e., much slower than the more familiar waves on the sea surface. In addition to both surface and internal waves, the ocean has a third type of fluid motion that lacks a well defined regular frequency. These are  ocean currents with time scales of weeks or months;  examples  include the meandering of the Gulf Stream and the pulsation of the Loop Current that lies off-shore of Florida in the Gulf of Mexico.  

These different types of fluid motion overlap and interact and present oceanographers and meteorologists  with a grand puzzle. This grant has made some progress in solving parts of that puzzle. For example, fifty years ago, oceanographers used a surface wave-sensing array offshore San Clemente Island to infer the location of sources of the swell coming from the Southern Ocean. These inferred sources were often as much as ten degrees (about 1000 kilometers) away from the storms reported on weather maps; a few  of the inferred wave sources were even on the Antarctic continent. Clearly these old measurements are either wrong or misleading, or both. In  this grant, with the benefit of modern measurements,  theory and computers, we have resolved this problem. We have used maps of ocean surface currents (based on satellite  measurements) and have   shown that surface  currents  significantly deflect swell generated in  the Southern Ocean:  on their one-week trip between the Southern Ocean and the coast of California these surface gravity  waves  do not travel along great circles. The errors in the classic measurements are akin to optical mirages.  The deflection of surface gravity waves by ocean currents must be considered for better forecasting of surface waves and for the interpretation of satellite data.

Another theme in our work has been to analyze the interaction of internal waves with ocean currents.  Time scales associated with internal  waves range from a few seconds to tens of hours, whereas  the time scales of ocean currents  range  from week to months. Thus oceanographers think of waves as "fast" and currents as "slow".  Resolving  both fast and slow motions over long time periods with a direct computer simulation of even a small part of the  ocean is impossible, even with the most powerful available supercomputers. Unless there are truly amazing advances in computer technology, this situation is unlikely to significantly improve in coming  decades.  Thus  theoretical investigations into the interaction between fast and slow motions are crucial  for our understanding of the ocean and the atmosphere. With that goal in mind, this grant has  elucidated the ways in which ocean internal waves, excited at  the sea surface by atmospheric storms, interact with slow meandering currents.  We have  used applied  mathematical analysis to systematically derive equations governing wave-current interactions. In carefully selected and formulated  test cases we have validated  this  mathematical theory  with direct numerical solution of the full equations of fluid motion.  


As part of the program outlined above, we have  discovered  a new class of wave-current interactions that transfer energy from currents to waves.  We have shown that this process, called stimulated loss of balance, is a significant sink of energy for currents and is important for the global energy balance of the ocean.
